awd_titl_txt: Self-Assembly of Peptide-based Nanosheets for 2D Nanoarchitectonics
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Vincent Conticello of Emory University is designing structurally defined, nanometer-sized two-dimensional assemblies from peptides, a basic structural building block of proteins.  A major challenge to science at nanometer scale dimensions is the ability to prepare structures with complete control over their sizes, shapes and chemical compositions.  Biology has shown that peptides, chemically linked sequences of amino acids, can assemble into a range of well-defined structures, so Professor Conticello is learning how to make synthetic versions of peptides and discover the rules by which they can be assembled into sheet-like structures.  The development of these relatively environmentally benign fabrication methods will promote the design and synthesis of nanoscale assemblies for use in a variety of applications that utilize optical, electronic, magnetic, or biological functions.

To meet this challenge, the Professor Conticello employs synthetic peptides of defined sequence and molecular architecture. The molecular-level information is utilized within a given structural context to direct highly specific intra- and inter-molecular interactions that promote self-assembly of thermodynamically stable and structurally defined two-dimensional assemblies.  Synthetic peptide structural motifs, including the collagen triple helix and the alpha-helix, are being examined as building blocks for the creation of the nanosheet assemblies. Structural characterization methods (X-ray fiber diffraction, solid-state NMR spectroscopy, and cryo-electron microscopy) are employed to define conditions to control the growth of the two-dimensional assemblies. Experimental conditions are being defined that will promote the integration of the nanosheet assemblies into more complex structures as a prelude to the creation of functional devices.  Under the direction of Professor Conticello, and in conjunction with the graduate students involved in this project, an outreach program is planned that will recruit undergraduate and high-school students to work on these inter-disciplinary studies at the interface of chemistry, biology, and materials science. In addition, a one-semester seminar session of the Emory course ORDER, On Recent Discoveries by Emory Researchers, is planned as a potentially sustainable trial to connect faculty, graduate students, post-docs and other materials-oriented investigators within the local EMORY community, to engage undergraduate students in order to more fully develop the connection between biological molecules and materials.

por.por_cntn:
Self-assembly is the primary mechanism through which the complex structures of biological systems arise. This process involves the formation of multiple weak interactions that are nonetheless structurally specific and thermally robust. The most common components of biological assemblies are proteins, which, through the sequence (order) and identity of amino acids, can fold into specific structures. Due to this structural and functional specificity, proteins have been considered as substrates for the fabrication of synthetic assemblies that would have potential applications in medicine and nanotechnology, if the principles that governed the assembly could be understood well enough to design novel protein-based materials.

We have established rules for the design of two-dimensional nano-scale assemblies (i.e., nanosheets) from small protein (i.e., peptide) structures. Two-dimensional protein assemblies are uncommon in nature, but are observed as major components in the cell envelopes of several classes of microbes. In these systems, the assemblies serve as a robust and responsive physical barrier that maintains the integrity of the organism. Inspired by these biological assemblies, synthetic peptide systems were designed that were capable of assembly in structurally defined nanosheet assemblies. The individual peptides adopted rod-like structures that enabled them to pack laterally into layered structures through electrostatic attractions programmed into the peptide sequence. The resultant nanosheets displayed crystalline order and were structurally and thermally robust.

Intellectual Merit: The controlled fabrication of two-dimensional assemblies on the nanoscale presents a significant challenge to current synthetic methods. Nonetheless, the development of effective fabrication practices is essential to the success of the emergent field of 2D nanoarchitectonics, in which chemical and physical principles are applied to engineer structurally defined nanosheet assemblies for integration into functional devices. The molecularly programmed self-assembly of sequence-defined peptides offers significant promise for the fabrication of 2D nanoarchitectonics. This investigation provided one of the first general design rubrics for fabrication of structurally defined nanosheets using the principles of solution-based self-assembly of bio-mimetic materials. During the course of this investigation, the following outcomes were obtained.

1. The development of structural principles that enabled the construction of 2D assemblies from simple peptide-based structural components such that the mechanical and thermal stability of the resultant nanosheets could be controlled. The properties of the nanosheets could be understood in terms of the interactions between amino acids in the respective peptide sequences.

2. The development of methods to control the extent of lateral growth and axial stacking of peptide-based nanosheets that enabled the construction of assemblies displaying defined dimensions.

3. Fabrication of 2D crystalline nano-porous assemblies that displayed hexagonal packing symmetry in which nanoscale channels (pores) formed.

4. The formation of hybrid biomaterials in which peptide nanosheets stacked alternately with DNA nanotiles in a highly ordered array.

Broader Impact: The development of the peptide nanosheets offers opportunities for the creation of novel functional materials for diverse applications. The surface chemistry of the nanosheets can be defined through mofication of sequence of the corresponding peptides. Moreover, in cases in which the dimensions have been defined, highly uniform populations of nanosheets can be obtained that should promote development of applications. The corresponded materials have been patented and are available for licensing. Best practice methods for experimental fabrication and detailed structural characterization of these peptide nanosheets have been published that serve as guide to researchers in this field.

This research has supported the intellectual growth and professional development of four graduate students that have defended their respective dissertations during the period of funding. Research collaborations have been initiated with the National Institute of Materials Science in Japan and have continued with Argonne National Lab and Brookhaven National Lab.
